NewsDetail.Name: What is an Integrated Curriculum? Lessons from the Online Task Force
NewsDetail.Title: What is an Integrated Curriculum? Lessons from the Online Task Force
NewsDetail.Abstract: As we discussed this question, there was broad consensus that online faculty personalize and make these courses “come alive” in ways that accentuate their unique and individual talents.
NewsDetail.Author: Ron Bennett and Clark Gilbert
NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
Should online courses replicate corresponding campus courses down to the most miniscule detail?  Or should they have an identity of their own, determined entirely by the instructors’ personal preferences, vision and teaching styles?  Or would the ideal mix be something in between those two extremes?

That is one of the questions discussed recently by a special committee on online learning at BYU-Idaho. Over the past three months, we have been participants in an Online Task Force comprised of Deans, Associate Deans, Department Chairs, and other faculty from across campus to counsel on issues related to the online learning initiative.  Topics have ranged from how to involve departments in the hiring of remote adjunct faculty, to the training of those instructors, to the measurement of learning.  Members of the task force have included:  Robyn Bergstrom (Business and Communications), Larry Thurgood (Education and Human Development), John Ivers (Language and Letters), Alan Dutson (Mechanical Engineering), Jon Linford (Music), Mark Bennion (English), Sid Palmer (Biology), Scott Galer (Foreign Language), Craig Bell (Business), Ron Bennett (Communication), Phil Allred (Religion), Peter Williams (Online), Matt Sanders (Online), Alan Young (Curriculum Development), and Clark Gilbert (Academic Office).

As a result of the discussions mentioned above, a key element of the BYU-Idaho Online Strategy has become the creation of an Integrated Curriculum.  The intent of this effort is that the online courses should be tied directly to the campus courses.  In other words, if a student takes a course online, the curriculum should be integrated to the corresponding on-campus course.  But what does this mean?  Or stated more formally:  “What is an integrated curriculum?” 

As we discussed this question, there was broad consensus that online faculty personalize and make these courses “come alive” in ways that accentuate their unique and individual talents.  But there was also a strong feeling that if we are going to offer these courses online there should also be real parameters around the curriculum itself.  This integration was to ensure quality and to tie online classes to campus offerings.  And while this integration was seen as important for the online courses, many of the task force members saw a similar need regarding Foundations courses on campus.  As one faculty member asked:  “How can you have teaching groups   if your curriculum is entirely different across sections?”

So, in a spirit of communication and shared learning, we would like to share five key dimensions that the task force felt were critical in creating an online curriculum that is integrated with campus:
  • Outcomes:  Learning outcomes are common among every section online and the main campus course.  Part of the online course development process includes not only the creation of the learning outcomes to match campus, but also the approval from campus Department Chairs or Associate Deans (in the case of Foundations).  The outcomes can be revised and a process is being developed to capture feedback from the online teaching group leaders, but changes to the online learning outcomes can only occur through the Team Leader and Course Development Team or Department.
  • Learning Model Architecture:  Each online course is built around an explicit Learning Model architecture with a corresponding learning cycle or rhythm.  Thecampus Course Development Team determines this architecture, which is built into the course design in I-Learn and remains a fixture of the course.  However, each of these course designs varies across courses.  For example, the online American Foundations course uses 13 weekly cycles with a set of Prepare, Teach One Another, and Ponder/Prove activities for each week.  The Family Foundations course uses six two-week cycles where different activities occur across each lesson.  The intent for online is that while specific learning activities and instructor styles may vary, the core architecture will remain common across each online section within a given course.
  • Content:  The ideas from this discussion pointed to a blend of fixed and elective content, determined again by the campus Team Lead and Course Development Team.  In other words, whether content is fixed, elective, or some blend of the two should be determined in the course design.  Of course if other suggestions come from the teaching of the course, those should be captured and suggested just as they are on campus.  But the general consensus from the task force was the creation of a “bounded choice” model, whose stewardship would continue to reside with the team leader on campus.  Scott Galer mentioned examples for this even on-campus where the Foreign Language Department requires campus adjunct to use certain texts in language instruction.  Sid Palmer gave similar examples from Biology materials and the need at a program level to be consistent, given content and course design across different programs.  Three general patterns were suggested, to be determined by the campus curriculum development team in the design of the course: 
    • Fixed Settings It was suggested that in some courses the content would be largely fixed, particularly in technical areas where the content is either linked directly to the outcomes or where it is cumulative across courses within a program.  Examples that were listed included Biology, Nursing, Engineering, Foreign Language and other courses where even some of the field tests are tied to specific content.  We also discussed the benefit of faculty (and students) accessing and discussing common content.  Examples discussed in the task force included Family Foundations where every student discusses the “Tyson Cases” (focused on different family dilemmas) or in Organizational Behavior where every student discusses the Robert Parsons Case (how to manage a high achiever who does not fit with the organization’s culture).
    • Bounded Choice The group also felt it would to important to provide an “options” list where the content could be flexible.  For example, instructors could choose from a list of content options, such as:  “Have students read and discuss an example of Social Satire literature.  We recommend Aldous Huxley’s Brave New World or George Orwell’s 1984. Discussion questions and learning activities for both are listed below.”  In this example, the curriculum provides bounded choice with supporting learning activities in the course design itself. 
    • Open OptionsIn other cases open options could be offered, either because the course content needs to be constantly evolving (current affairs, specific technologies, etc.) or because variance on the content can happen within the stated learning outcomes for the course.  It was suggested that the course template always include a suggested piece of content or an option set (there is always a recommended option), but that one of the options to the instructors could include:  “Choose Content A OR look for additional outside reading on this subject and build a learning activity around it that follows the similar pattern above.”
  • Teaching Plans:  The ideas regarding teaching plans were similar in principle to “Content” but even more dynamic.  The way an online instructor engages the content becomes an area with the highest level of personal and professional adaptation.  There was a suggestion that each course be built with a “master” teaching plan, but that faculty members should be able to adapt their own teaching plan in ways that work for them and learn organically from what others are doing.  We discussed two dimensions of this concept: 
    • Learning Activities:Are the learning activities fixed?  For example, can the online instructor choose to do a blog instead of a discussion board?  Can he or she choose to do a problem-based activity vs. a group project?  The feeling of the group was that Learning Strategies should look similar to content, but have even more choice and flexibility.  It was assumed that there would be some activities that were fixed into the course design, but both bounded and open options would provide many more choices.
    • Specific Engagement Strategies:This might include the questions an online instructor uses to open a discussion or different strategies to engage a specific learning activity.  For example, can the online instructor change the opening question in a discussion board in American Foundations from:  “What drove the split between Hamilton and Madison after they wrote The Federalist Papers?” to “How did being from Virginia vs. New York impact the philosophical tension between Madison and Hamilton?”  On this topic, the task force was comfortable with a broader degree of flexibility as long as the strategy supported the lesson’s learning outcomes.
  • Assessments: The task force felt these should be fixed for each course and determined again by the campus Team Leader and the Course Development Team.  Some design flexibility should be built in to accommodate content choices employed by the online instructor.  However, that decision still rests with the campus development team as to where and how that happens.
We will continue to learn as we progress.  What became clear from the discussions was that a lot depended on where you stood.  When campus faculty considered their own teaching, they felt strongly that curriculum should be quite open.  When they considered online courses, they were much more concerned about consistency and integration with campus.  We believe we are moving toward something that balances both concerns and will help us provide a high quality online learning experience that is tied to campus.
